Mr. Bennet's property consisted almost entirely in an estate of two thousand a year, which, unfortunately for his daughters, was entailed, in default of heirs male, on a distant relation; and their mother's fortune, though ample for her situation in life, could but ill supply the deficiency of his. Her father had been an attorney in Meryton, and had left her four thousand pounds. The village of Longbourn was only one mile from Meryton; a most convenient distance for the young ladies, who were usually tempted thither three or four times a week, to pay their duty to their aunt and to a milliner's shop just over the way. The two youngest of the family, Catherine and Lydia, were particularly frequent in these attentions; their minds were more vacant than their sisters', and when nothing better offered, a walk to Meryton was necessary to amuse their morning hours and furnish conversation for the evening; and however bare of news the country in general might be, they always contrived to learn some from their aunt. At present, indeed, they were well supplied both with news and happiness by the recent arrival of a militia regiment in the neighbourhood; it was to remain the whole winter, and Meryton was the headquarters.

en_results_raw: family so little worth noticing! If you can think that she was applied to by them in this manner for anything but to discover whether she had any other house that would suit it better. You must remember that when she was a girl, she was always plain; and by her own confession, unformed. My dear Jane, I am quite vexed that you should be so deluded. You will not like her so well when you know her better; but whether you will ever be reconciled to her representing so great a beauty as Miss Darcy, is another affair. I am not qualified to judge of her beauty, as men are; but I can see no beauty about her. Her features are not at all handsome. Her nose wants character; there is nothing marked or distinguished about it. She is not a beauty, nor ever will be. She has nothing to recommend her, but a tolerable carriage, and a very good complexion; and these are not the qualities which a man of sense and education is likely to look for in a wife. You will see her, therefore, in her proper light, and be able to judge for yourself; but as for me, I am quite convinced that she is nothing but a very common sort of girl, and I am afraid of her being very proud and disagreeable.”

Now, I know very well that you are not used to eating anything between breakfast and dinner, but pray stay and take some refreshment with us, if it is only to prevent our being monstrous cross for the rest of the day. Louisa is in hopes you will, and has been at some pains to make something worth your eating. She has made some excellent macaroni and cheese, and some little cakes that are not bad. I am sure you will like them, and I dare say you will eat a great deal, for you must be hungry after your journey. We dine at three, and I shall expect you at half-past two, for I know you will not like to come in in the middle of dinner. I am afraid we shall have a very dull day, for it is raining, and the weather looks very gloomy, but we shall do our best to make it as pleasant as we can. I hope you will not be too much bored, and that you will be able to amuse yourself tolerably well. The fresh air, the green fields, the songs of the birds, and the peacefulness of the surroundings, all combine to make the country a more desirable residence for those who value their health and their tranquility. In contrast, London is a bustling metropolis, full of noise, crowds, and distractions, where one can easily get lost in the hustle and bustle of city life. While it may offer many advantages, such as access to education, culture, and entertainment, it can also be overwhelming and stressful for those who are not accustomed to it. Ultimately, the choice between London and the country depends on one's personal preferences and priorities.

en_results_raw: that I have never been in the habit of making public declarations of my sentiments, nor of justifying my conduct to the world in general. I have always considered it a matter of private concern, and one in which I am accountable only to myself and those immediately connected with me. I must confess, however, that I am a little surprised at the pertinacity with which you pursue this subject, and the eagerness with which you seem to wish to fix on me the imputation of harbouring opinions which I have never avowed. Can it be that you are anxious to establish a claim to my confidence, or to induce me to make some declaration which may be used to my disadvantage? I must own that I am not without some suspicion of this kind, and I must entreat you, Miss Bennet, to be cautious how you proceed. Your zeal, though it may be well-intentioned, may lead you into errors and difficulties from which it may be difficult to extricate yourself. I would advise you, therefore, to be more guarded in your expressions, and to be careful not to commit yourself to any opinions or sentiments which you may afterwards find it inconvenient to maintain.

I listened intently, my mind racing with possibilities, and when he finished, I knew that my life would never be the same again.

en_first_half: “That is all very proper and civil, I am sure,” said Mrs. Bennet, “and I dare say she is a very
en_second_half: agreeable woman. It is a pity that great ladies in general are not more like her. Does she live near you, sir?”
en_results: agreeable girl. She is pretty, to be sure, and the young men seem to think her so; but I do not know that I should
en_results_raw: agreeable girl. She is pretty, to be sure, and the young men seem to think her so; but I do not know that I should have chosen her for a daughter-in-law, had I been you, Mr. Bennet. She is not a woman of many attractions, and her family is not very respectable. Her father is a gentleman of very little property, and her mother is a woman of no understanding. I do not know how they will be able to support their daughters, and I fear they will be a burden to you and your family. But, as you have made your choice, I suppose it is not for me to object. I only hope that you will be happy, and that your marriage will be a prosperous one." Mrs. Bennet then turned to her husband, and said, "I do hope, Mr. Bennet, that you will not forget to speak to Mr. Bingley about the living at Netherfield. It would be a great advantage to us, and I am sure he would be willing to do it, if you were to ask him." Mr. Bennet, who had been listening to his wife's conversation with a mixture of amusement and annoyance, replied, "I shall certainly speak to Mr. Bingley about it, my dear, but I must say that I do not think it is a very likely thing. He is a young man of large fortune, and I do not think he will be very anxious to settle a living on a young man of no family or connections." Mrs. Bennet looked at her husband with a mixture of surprise and disappointment, and said, "But, Mr. Bennet, you must know that it is of the utmost importance to us. We must have a settled income, or we shall be ruined. And I am sure that Mr. Bingley would be willing to do it, if you were to ask him in the right way." Mr. Bennet sighed, and said, "I shall speak to him, my dear, but I must say that I do not think it is a very likely thing."

Mr. Darcy, who was leaning against the mantelpiece with his eyes fixed on her face, seemed to catch the whole history of it in her hurried and incoherent words, and to see in them the confirmation of his own suspicions. He had no doubt now of Miss Bennet's meaning, and was convinced that she had been imposed upon by the arts of a designing woman. He was not sorry to have the affair explained, and was rather glad to have an opportunity of speaking his mind, and of justifying his conduct to the lady whom he had so grossly injured. "I must confess, Miss Bennet," said he, "that I am not at all surprised at what you have told me. I had suspected as much, and I must say that I am not at all sorry to have my suspicions confirmed. I have been grossly deceived, and I have been the means of injuring one who, I believe, is as innocent as myself." He paused a moment, and then added, "I must beg your pardon, Miss Bennet, for my behaviour to you. I have been guilty of a great error, and I hope you will forgive me." Elizabeth was surprised at his words, and did not know what to say. She had expected him to be angry, and to justify his conduct, but she had not expected him to acknowledge his error, and to ask her pardon. She was pleased with his behaviour, and was glad to see that he was capable of feeling and of acting with generosity. "I forgive you, Mr. Darcy," said she, "and I hope that you will forgive me for my part in the business. I was deceived, and I was foolish, but I was also young and ignorant, and I hope that you will not think the worse of me for it." Mr. Darcy bowed, and smiled, and the two shook hands, and the affair was settled. They stood for a moment, looking at each other, and then Mr. Darcy turned to the door, and said, "I must go, Miss Bennet. I have a long journey before me, and I must not delay. I hope that you will not forget me, and that you will sometimes think of me." Elizabeth smiled, and said, "I shall not forget you, Mr. Darcy. I shall often think of you, and I shall always remember our conversation with pleasure." Mr. Darcy bowed, and went out, and Elizabeth was left alone to think over what had passed. She was pleased with the way the affair had ended, and she was glad to have had the opportunity of speaking her mind, and of justifying her conduct. She was also glad to have seen Mr. Darcy, and to have found that he was not so proud and disagreeable as she had thought him. She had always disliked him, but now she began to think that she had been mistaken, and that he was not so bad as she had supposed. en_results_raw: to say to each other. We were both listening, though I to nobody. There was nothing to listen to, but the sound of the music and the occasional laugh or exclamation from the card-tables. I was not attending to either, my eyes being fixed on the door, when Sir William, after a short conversation with the lady of the house, made his way through the crowd to our corner of the room. I was surprised to see him, and still more surprised when he addressed me, as he did in a very friendly manner, and inquired how I had been since our last meeting. I told him I had been very well, and he asked me if I had been in town long. I said I had been in town a fortnight, and he replied that he had been in town only a few days. He then asked me if I had seen any of our common friends, and I told him I had seen none, as I had been very little out. He said he had seen several of them, and mentioned one or two names, but I did not know them. He then asked me if I would like to play at whist, and I said I would, if he would find me a partner. He said he would, and went away to look for one. I was left standing alone, and I began to feel a little awkward, as I did not know anybody in the room, and I was not acquainted with the lady of the house. I looked round the room, but I did not see Sir William, and I began to think that he had forgotten me. Just then, I heard a voice behind me, and I turned round to see a gentleman standing there, who bowed to me and said, "I believe Sir William has asked me to play at whist with you." I said I believed so, and he asked me if I was ready to begin. I said I was, and we went to the card-table together.

My reasons for believing it are briefly these:—It does not appear to me that my hand is unworthy your acceptance, or that the establishment I can offer would be any other than highly desirable. My situation in life, my connections with the family of De Bourgh, and my relationship to your own, are circumstances highly in my favour; and you should take it
en_second_half: into further consideration that, in spite of your manifold attractions, it is by no means certain that another offer of marriage may ever be made you. Your portion is unhappily so small, that it will in all likelihood undo the effects of your loveliness and amiable qualifications. As I must, therefore, conclude that you are not serious in your rejection of me, I shall choose to attribute it to your wish of increasing my love by suspense, according to the usual practice of elegant females.”

en_results_raw: house with him for so many hours together, would be more than I could bear; and before I had any right to give a denial. This will be a trial to be sure; but after all, only a trial. If he does not come to me, then I shall think you the most miserable of beings." "Yours, &c." Mr. Darcy's letter to Mr. Bingley was delivered, and he read it with great surprise and concern. He had not expected such a letter from his friend, and he could hardly believe that Mr. Darcy could be so mistaken in his opinion of Elizabeth. He immediately wrote a reply, and sent it off by express, hoping to prevent any further misunderstanding. Meanwhile, Elizabeth was at home, anxiously awaiting the arrival of Mr. Darcy, and wondering what the outcome of their meeting would be. She had not expected him to write to Mr. Bingley, and she was both surprised and relieved when she heard that he had done so. As the day wore on, she became more and more agitated, and she could hardly eat or sleep, so great was her anxiety. At last, the moment of their meeting arrived, and Elizabeth's heart beat with anticipation as she saw Mr. Darcy enter the room. He looked grave and serious, and Elizabeth's heart sank as she saw the expression on his face. But as he approached her, she saw a glimmer of hope in his eyes, and she felt a sense of relief wash over her. "Miss Bennet," he said, bowing low, "I hope you are well." Elizabeth curtsied, and replied, "I am, thank you, Mr. Darcy." They stood for a moment in silence, and then Mr. Darcy spoke again. "I must apologize for my behavior at our last meeting," he said. "I was wrong to speak to you as I did, and I hope you will forgive me." Elizabeth's heart was full of emotion as she listened to his words, and she felt a sense of joy and relief that she had not felt in a long time. "I forgive you, Mr. Darcy," she said, smiling up at him. "And I hope that we can put the past behind us and start anew." Mr. Darcy's face lit up with a warm smile, and he took Elizabeth's hand in his. "I hope so too, my dear," he said. "I hope so too."

Elizabeth escuchaba atentamente, sintiendo que se estaba conectando con su hermana de una manera que no había experimentado en mucho tiempo. Después del desayuno, decidieron salir a explorar la ciudad juntas, disfrutando del sol y del aire fresco. La risa y la conversación fluyeron con facilidad, y Elizabeth se sintió agradecida de haber podido compartir este momento con su hermana. His regard for her was not unlike that of a man who has been long accustomed to the enjoyment of a certain luxury, and who, when deprived of it, feels a strong sense of discomfort, but is not deeply grieved. He had been so used to the idea of marrying her, that he could not easily reconcile himself to the loss of it; but he was not in love with her, and therefore did not feel that deep and lasting regret which a man of stronger feelings would have experienced in his situation. He was more vexed than grieved, and his anger was heightened by the reflection that he had been foolish enough to suppose her in love with him, and to imagine that she would be happy in his society. He was convinced that she had never been in love with him, and that her refusal was not the result of any change in her sentiments, but merely of her having discovered that she had never loved him. This conviction, though it did not diminish his vexation, served to restore his pride, and he began to think that he had been very foolish to suppose that a woman of her sense and beauty would ever have accepted him.

But the whole of the letter was not contained in that line; it was now absolutely settled between them that her brother would not marry Miss Darcy, and at the thought of such a possibility, she could not help laughing at herself for her former apprehensions. She felt that she had been unreasonable, and that her fears had been ridiculous; and though she did not mean to be unkind, she could not help blaming herself for the pain she had given her sister. She was now perfectly convinced that her brother would not marry Miss Darcy; and she was glad of it, for she did not think her brother would be happy with her, and she was rather sorry that he had ever thought of it. She was now in hopes of being soon able to make her sister easy about it, and was anxious to communicate the intelligence to her as soon as possible.

She was particularly pleased to hear that Mr. Bingley was to be at the ball, and she could not help expressing her hope that he would dance with one of her daughters. Mr. Bennet, who had been watching his wife's countenance, observed that she was in high spirits, and he could not help smiling at her evident delight. He knew that she was anxious to see her daughters married, and he was amused by her eagerness to promote their interests. As the evening drew to a close, Mrs. Bennet's thoughts turned to the ball, and she began to make plans for the dresses and the preparations that would be necessary. The next morning, however, he sought an opportunity of addressing her, as he entered the breakfast-room, to apologize for his behaviour; and though she declared that she was not at all offended, his countenance told her that he was not satisfied with himself. They were joined by Mr. Collins, who, with great politeness, and with an air of perfect indifference, congratulated them on the approaching nuptials of his cousin, and moved to the window to admire the prospect. Elizabeth, however, could not help observing, as he took up some book, that her loss had been his gain, and that the change in the disposition of the family, in favour of his nearest relations, must be a very agreeable one to him. She saw, with a glance of dismay, that he was reading the letter which had been written the day before, and her feelings were in a tumult of alarm and distress. She knew not what to do, nor how to behave, and was only relieved from her embarrassment by the entrance of the servant with the breakfast. Mr. Collins, with very little notice, immediately and very civilly took leave, and Elizabeth, who had been watching him with great anxiety, was relieved to see him go, and to find that she was once more alone with her sister. She then took an opportunity of speaking to her, and expressed her fears and apprehensions in a manner that was not to be misunderstood. Jane listened to her with great attention, and, though she could not help feeling some surprise at the warmth of her expressions, she was, on the whole, convinced of the sincerity of her sister's feelings, and was satisfied that she was not mistaken in her opinion of Mr. Collins. The conversation was soon interrupted by the arrival of the post, and the reading of the letters which it brought, and Elizabeth, who had been watching the countenance of her sister, was relieved to see that she was not so much affected by the intelligence which they contained, as she had been by the conversation which had just passed. en_first_half: He came, and in such very good time, that the ladies were none of them dressed. In
en_second_half: ran Mrs. Bennet to her daughters’ room, in her dressing-gown, and with her hair half finished, crying out,—
en_results: fact, they were only just beginning to dress, and were still in their morning wrappers, with their hair in papers,
en_results_raw: fact, they were only just beginning to dress, and were still in their morning wrappers, with their hair in papers, when he was announced. The surprise was great, and the confusion greater, as they hastened to make themselves presentable, while he was ushered into the drawing-room to await their appearance. Mrs. Bennet, who had been in high spirits all the morning, was now in a state of utmost agitation, and her daughters were not much better, as they hurried to complete their toilettes, and make a decent appearance before their unexpected guest. Meanwhile, Mr. Bingley, who was a tall, handsome young man, with a pleasant countenance and easy manners, was left to amuse himself in the drawing-room, where he walked about, taking note of the furniture and the pictures, and occasionally glancing at his watch, as if he was anxious for the ladies to make their appearance.
